text.__SUMMARY__: Gregory's wolf (Canis lupus gregoryi), also known as the Mississippi Valley wolf, is a subspecies of the gray wolf. It was declared extinct in 1980. It once roamed the regions in and around the lower Mississippi River basin.
text.Taxonomy: This wolf is recognized as a subspecies of Canis lupus in the taxonomic authority Mammal Species of the World (2005). At one time, this canid was proposed by some authors as a subspecies of the red wolf.
text.Description:
This subspecies is described as being larger than the red wolf, but more slender and tawny. Its coloring includes a combination of black, grey, and white, along with a large amount of cinnamon coloring along the back of its body and the top of its head. It weighs around 60 pounds (27 kg) to 70 pounds (32 kg), on average.
